title: Lauren Bell and New York Tales
description: England bowler Lauren Bell and our Jimmy ‚Äònerd out‚Äô on remodelled actions, out swingers, biomechanics and training regimes. Plus baseball, bad food, awards, dead ducks and almost a quiz from Mattchin.

title: Will Bangladesh reap rewards despite not hosting ICC Women‚Äôs T20 World Cup?
description: Alison Mitchell is alongside Charu Sharma and Jim Maxwell to discuss the effects on women‚Äôs cricket in Bangladesh, with the country not hosting the Women‚Äôs ICC T20 World Cup. Bangladesh cricket writer Tawhid Qureshi gives his thoughts on how the domestic game in Bangladesh would have benefited from the spotlight that hosting a World Cup brings, and how Bangladeshi players need more pathways to the professional game.Ali, Jim & Charu reflect on Joe Root becoming England‚Äôs men‚Äôs leading run-scorer in Tests and on his compatriot Harry Brook scoring a triple century in the first Test in Multan against Pakistan.Plus, they find out more about cricket‚Äôs inventors and innovators by talking to Stuart Robertson ‚Äì the inventor of T20 cricket.
author: BBC World Service

title: Jason Gillespie on putting faith in his Pakistan players
description: Alison Mitchell is alongside Charu Sharma and Jim Maxwell to discuss Pakistan hosting England in a three-test series, which begins on 7 October.Alison speaks to Pakistan red-ball head coach Jason Gillespie ahead of the series with the new coach looking to turn around Pakistan‚Äôs fortunes, with just two wins in their last thirteen Tests. He talks about wanting to instill belief in his squad, as well as managing his captain Shan Masood and improving the squad‚Äôs fitness.Plus, Ali, Jim & Charu find out the origin of one of cricket‚Äôs iconic techniques - the ‚ÄòGoogly‚Äô.Photo Credit: Pakistan men's test team head coach Jason Gillespie speaks to the media at National Bank Cricket Stadium on July 07, 2024 in Karachi, Pakistan. (Photo by Muhammad Sameer Ali/Getty Images).
author: BBC World Service

title: Alec Stewart looks back on success with Surrey
description: Kevin Howells is alongside Surrey correspondent Mark Church to speak to former Surrey Director of Cricket Alec Stewart.They discuss Stewart‚Äôs legacy as he moves into a new role with Surrey, as well as his thoughts on the long-term future of the County Championship and how Dan Worrall was his ‚Äúbest signing‚Äù at the club
author: BBC Radio 5 Live

title: Leach leads England to magnificent Multan victory
description: Jonathan Agnew is alongside Steven Finn & Aatif Nawaz for reaction to England‚Äôs victory in the first Test against Pakistan at Multan. They discuss whether Ben Stokes will return for the second Test in the series and how Pakistan let England back into the game from a strong position . Hear from the captains, Ollie Pope and Shan Masood, as well as debutant Brydon Carse who took four wickets for England.

title: Five Hundred and You Lose (by an innings.)
description: Simon Hughes and Simon Mann review a remarkable victory for England in Multan after conceding 556 in the first innings. title: Root and Brook masterclass was a beautiful warning about Test cricket‚Äôs end days | Barney Ronay
description: Their partnership was staggering but it can‚Äôt hide that all the talent and money is being bent now towards the churn of interchangeable franchise cricketEt in Arcadia ego. One of the most striking parts of sport, outside the endless tribal rage, the venal commercialising of play, the alienation of the basic human experience to the extent people are now literately referred to as ‚Äúeyeballs‚Äù (why not ‚Äúdead souls‚Äù? Or just borrow straight from the bit of merchant banking where customers are referred to as ‚Äúshitheads‚Äù) or indeed the way every single ‚Ä¶ Hang on. Where was I?Yes. One of the best parts of sport is its ability to create clean, crisp, distinct islands of beauty. Sport still offers that quiet space. There is wonder here, and clarity on its own terms. It is also still the case that nothing does this quite like Test cricket. Continue reading...
author: Barney Ronay

title: England making themselves at home in world of cricket wonderment
description: Records tumbled in an unforgettable first Test, but for England‚Äôs Ollie Pope nothing comes as a surpriseIn the moments after the first Test ended on Friday, in the warm ‚Äì verging on searing, given the conditions ‚Äì glow of a remarkable victory over Pakistan, Ollie Pope was asked where it ranked among the games he has been involved in over the past couple of years.Considering the mind-spinning absurdity of the match that had just finished, and the amount of history made over the previous five days ‚Äì shattering the nation‚Äôs 67-year-old record for highest partnership, becoming the first team to concede 500 runs and win by an innings, posting England‚Äôs highest score since 1938 and the highest ever compiled in Pakistan, England‚Äôs greatest individual innings since 1990, plus Joe Root becoming their leading Test run-scorer of all time, not bad for a few days‚Äô work ‚Äì his response was surprising: ‚ÄúIt would be right up there,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúDefinitely top three.‚Äù Continue reading...
author: Simon Burnton in Multan
